Hierarchical gaussian models, empirical bayes and shrinkage

Overview

This article is the second of the Bayesian series. Previous episode here.
You probably already know the Bayes theorem or stumble upon Naive Bayes when comparing machine learning models. Maybe, like me, you feel that you barely saw the shores of the continent that is the Bayesian land and want to set foot in it.
I wrote this article from a Stanford course with the intent for you to understand the relationships between all Bayesian concepts without having to go through an entire classroom (like I did). As a matter of readability, I hide most of the maths in dropdowns. This way, you can follow the logic easily and come back to deep dive into formulas later.
So far we have dealt with Bayesian analysis of very simple models, mainly using conjugate priors, with few parameters to estimate. In the coin tossing example, we had just one parameter, the probability of heads. In the Gaussian model, we had two parameters, the mean ŒºŒºŒºÔªø and variance œÉ2œÉ^2œÉ2Ôªø. However, in modern applications one typically must estimate many parameters, using more complicated hierarchical models.

1. Empirical Bayes

1.1 Estimation of the normal mean

Suppose that we have NNNÔªø observations each from independent Gaussians all with same variance 1 but with different means
yi‚ÄÖ‚Ää‚àºindN(Œºi,1)y_i \;\sim^{ind}N(\mu_i,1)yi‚Äã‚àºindN(Œºi‚Äã,1)Ôªø‚Äã
This is a high-dimensional model: there are as many parameters as there are data. Another way to write it with N-vectors:
y‚ÄÖ‚Ää‚àº‚ÄÖ‚ÄäN(IŒº,I)y\;\sim\;N(I\mu,I)y‚àºN(IŒº,I)Ôªø‚Äã
Suppose we want to estimate the vector Œº. The natural ‚Äúfrequentist‚Äù thing to do is just to use the MLE, which in this case is simply
Œº^=y\hat{\mu}=yŒº^‚Äã=yÔªø‚Äã
On the other hand, if we performed a Bayesian analysis, it would be natural to choose the prior
Œºi‚ÄÖ‚Ää‚àºiid‚ÄÖ‚ÄäN(m,œÑ2)\mu_i\;\sim^{iid}\;N(m,\tau^2)Œºi‚Äã‚àºiidN(m,œÑ2)Ôªø‚Äã
We compute the difference of risk between the frequentist MLE and the Bayes estimator
Frequentist
The risk of the MLE (yiy_iyi‚ÄãÔªø) is the expectation of its squared error loss
E[‚à£‚à£Œº‚àíŒº^‚à£‚à£22]=‚àëi=1NE[(Œºi‚àíŒº^i)2]=‚àëi=1NE[(Œºi‚àíyi)2]=NE[||\mu-\hat{\mu}||^2_2]=\sum^N_{i=1}E[(\mu_i-\hat{\mu}_i)^2]=\sum^N_{i=1}E[(\mu_i-y_i)^2]=NE[‚à£‚à£Œº‚àíŒº^‚Äã‚à£‚à£22‚Äã]=‚àëi=1N‚ÄãE[(Œºi‚Äã‚àíŒº^‚Äãi‚Äã)2]=‚àëi=1N‚ÄãE[(Œºi‚Äã‚àíyi‚Äã)2]=NÔªø‚Äã
since the yiy_iyi‚ÄãÔªø are all independent normals with mean ŒºiŒº_iŒºi‚ÄãÔªø and variance 1.
Bayesian:
The Bayes estimator of each ŒºiŒº_iŒºi‚ÄãÔªø is
E[Œºi‚à£y,m,œÑ2]=yi1+œÑ‚àí2E[\mu_i|y,m,\tau^2]=\frac{y_i}{1+\tau^{-2}}E[Œºi‚Äã‚à£y,m,œÑ2]=1+œÑ‚àí2yi‚Äã‚ÄãÔªø‚Äã
This is given by the following theorem, when we consider m‚ÄÑ=‚ÄÑ0.
If y‚àºN(Œº,Œ£)y \sim N(\mu, \Sigma)y‚àºN(Œº,Œ£)Ôªø and Œº‚àºN(m,Œ®)\mu \sim N(m, \Psi)Œº‚àºN(m,Œ®)Ôªø then y‚à£Œº‚àºN(VŒæ,V)y|\mu \sim N(V\xi, V)y‚à£Œº‚àºN(VŒæ,V)Ôªø‚Äã
Where V=(Œ®‚àí1+Œ£‚àí1)‚àí1,‚ÄÖ‚ÄäŒæ=(Œ®‚àí1m+Œ£‚àí1y)V = (\Psi^{-1}+\Sigma^{-1})^{-1},\;\xi = (\Psi^{-1}m + \Sigma^{-1}y)V=(Œ®‚àí1+Œ£‚àí1)‚àí1,Œæ=(Œ®‚àí1m+Œ£‚àí1y)Ôªø‚Äã
So the posterior means shrinks the MLE. Let‚Äôs compute the frequentist risk of this estimator, which is needed to obtain the Bayes risk.
E(yiœÑ21+œÑ2‚àíŒºi)2=var(yiœÑ21+œÑ2)+bias2(yiœÑ21+œÑ2)=œÑ4(1+œÑ2)2+Œºi2(1+œÑ2)2E(\frac{y_i\tau^2}{1+\tau^2}-\mu_i)^2=var(\frac{y_i\tau^2}{1+\tau^2})+bias^2(\frac{y_i\tau^2}{1+\tau^2})=\frac{\tau^4}{(1+\tau^2)^2}+\frac{\mu_i^2}{(1+\tau^2)^2}E(1+œÑ2yi‚ÄãœÑ2‚Äã‚àíŒºi‚Äã)2=var(1+œÑ2yi‚ÄãœÑ2‚Äã)+bias2(1+œÑ2yi‚ÄãœÑ2‚Äã)=(1+œÑ2)2œÑ4‚Äã+(1+œÑ2)2Œºi2‚Äã‚ÄãÔªø‚Äã
So the Bayes risk of this estimator is
‚àëiEm,œÑ2[œÑ4(1+œÑ2)2+Œºi2(1+œÑ2)2]=NEm,œÑ2[œÑ4(1+œÑ2)2+Œºi2(1+œÑ2)2]=NœÑ2œÑ2+1\sum_i E_{m,\tau^2}[\frac{\tau^4}{(1+\tau^2)^2}+\frac{\mu_i^2}{(1+\tau^2)^2}]=NE_{m,\tau^2}[\frac{\tau^4}{(1+\tau^2)^2}+\frac{\mu_i^2}{(1+\tau^2)^2}]=N\frac{\tau^2}{\tau^2+1}‚àëi‚ÄãEm,œÑ2‚Äã[(1+œÑ2)2œÑ4‚Äã+(1+œÑ2)2Œºi2‚Äã‚Äã]=NEm,œÑ2‚Äã[(1+œÑ2)2œÑ4‚Äã+(1+œÑ2)2Œºi2‚Äã‚Äã]=NœÑ2+1œÑ2‚ÄãÔªø‚Äã
So the difference between the risk of the MLE and the Bayes estimator is
N‚àíNœÑ2œÑ2+1=NœÑ2+1N-N\frac{\tau^2}{\tau^2+1}=\frac{N}{\tau^2+1}N‚àíNœÑ2+1œÑ2‚Äã=œÑ2+1N‚ÄãÔªø‚Äã
Rfrequentist‚àíRBayesian=NœÑ2+1R_{frequentist}-R_{Bayesian}=\frac{N}{\tau^2+1}Rfrequentist‚Äã‚àíRBayesian‚Äã=œÑ2+1N‚ÄãÔªø, which can be very large if œÑ is small.

1.2 Admissibility and Empirical Bayes

Obviously we want estimators that have low risk. For any loss function LLLÔªø we know that:
Frequentist deal with the fact that Œ∏\thetaŒ∏Ôªø is unknown, the risk still depends on Œ∏Œ∏Œ∏Ôªø‚Äã
R(Œ∏,Œ¥)=‚à´L(Œ∏,Œ¥(y))p(y‚à£Œ∏))dyR(\theta,\delta)=\int L(\theta,\delta(y))p(y|\theta))dyR(Œ∏,Œ¥)=‚à´L(Œ∏,Œ¥(y))p(y‚à£Œ∏))dyÔªø‚Äã
Bayesians deal with this issue by integrating a second time over Œ∏\thetaŒ∏Ôªø with respect to the prior distribution.
RÀâ=‚à´‚à´L(Œ∏,Œ¥(y))p(y‚à£Œ∏)p(Œ∏‚à£Œæ)dydŒ∏=EŒæ[EŒ∏[L(Œ∏,Œ¥(y))]]\bar{R}=\int \int L(\theta,\delta(y))p(y|\theta)p(\theta|\xi)dyd\theta=E_{\xi}[E_{\theta}[L(\theta,\delta(y))]]RÀâ=‚à´‚à´L(Œ∏,Œ¥(y))p(y‚à£Œ∏)p(Œ∏‚à£Œæ)dydŒ∏=EŒæ‚Äã[EŒ∏‚Äã[L(Œ∏,Œ¥(y))]]Ôªø‚Äã
Where Œæ are prior hyperparameters. However frequentists don‚Äôt use prior, so instead we can use admissibility and minimax.
An estimator Œ¥‚àó\delta^*Œ¥‚àóÔªø is inadmissible if there exists another estimator Œ¥\deltaŒ¥Ôªø for which:
R(Œ∏,Œ¥)‚â§R(Œ∏,Œ¥‚àó)R(\theta,\delta)\leq R(\theta,\delta^*)R(Œ∏,Œ¥)‚â§R(Œ∏,Œ¥‚àó)Ôªø‚Äã
So an estimator is admissible if it is not inadmissible. Œ¥\deltaŒ¥Ôªø dominate Œ¥‚àó\delta^*Œ¥‚àóÔªø if R(Œ∏,‚ÄÜŒ¥)‚â§R(Œ∏,‚ÄÜŒ¥‚àó)R(Œ∏,‚ÄÜŒ¥)‚â§R(Œ∏,‚ÄÜŒ¥^*)R(Œ∏,‚ÄÜŒ¥)‚â§R(Œ∏,‚ÄÜŒ¥‚àó)Ôªø for every Œ∏\thetaŒ∏Ôªø.

1.3 The James-Stein estimator

If we don‚Äôt know how to choose the parameter œÑ\tauœÑÔªø of Œº\muŒºÔªø, we try to estimate Œº\muŒºÔªø using empirical Bayes via the James-Stein estimator.
Œº^(JS)=(1‚àíN‚àí2‚à£‚à£y‚à£‚à£2)‚ÄÖ‚Ääy\hat{\mu}^{(JS)}=(1-\frac{N-2}{||y||^2})\;yŒº^‚Äã(JS)=(1‚àí‚à£‚à£y‚à£‚à£2N‚àí2‚Äã)yÔªø‚Äã
We prove that the JS estimator has a larger risk than the Bayes estimator (indeed it must be), but it dominates the MLE everywhere if the dimension is large enough (N‚ÄÑ‚â•‚ÄÑ2).
So we have
y‚à£Œº‚ÄÖ‚Ää‚àº‚ÄÖ‚ÄäN(Œº,I),‚ÄÖ‚ÄäŒº‚à£œÑ2‚ÄÖ‚Ää‚àº‚ÄÖ‚ÄäN(0,œÑ2I)y|\mu\;\sim\;N(\mu,I),\;\mu|\tau^2\;\sim \; N(0,\tau^2I)y‚à£Œº‚àºN(Œº,I),Œº‚à£œÑ2‚àºN(0,œÑ2I)Ôªø‚Äã
and
y‚ÄÖ‚Ää‚àº‚ÄÖ‚ÄäN(0,(1+œÑ2)I).y\;\sim\;N(0,(1+\tau^2)I).y‚àºN(0,(1+œÑ2)I).Ôªø‚Äã
Thus
S=‚à£‚à£y‚à£‚à£2‚ÄÖ‚Ää‚üπ‚ÄÖ‚ÄäS‚ÄÖ‚Ää‚àº‚ÄÖ‚Ää(œÑ2+1)œáN2S=||y||^2 \implies S\;\sim\;(\tau^2+1)\chi^2_NS=‚à£‚à£y‚à£‚à£2‚üπS‚àº(œÑ2+1)œáN2‚ÄãÔªø‚Äã
where œáN2\chi^2_NœáN2‚ÄãÔªø has N degrees of freedom and
E[N‚àí2S]=1œÑ2+1E[\frac{N-2}{S}]=\frac{1}{\tau^2+1}E[SN‚àí2‚Äã]=œÑ2+11‚ÄãÔªø‚Äã
With our JS estimator defined as
Œº^(JS)=(1‚àíN‚àí2S)‚ÄÖ‚Ääy\hat{\mu}^{(JS)}=(1-\frac{N-2}{S})\;yŒº^‚Äã(JS)=(1‚àíSN‚àí2‚Äã)yÔªø‚Äã
the integrated risk of our JS estimator is:
R(Œº,Œº^(JS))=EŒº[‚à£‚à£Œº‚àíŒº^(JS)‚à£‚à£2]=EŒº[‚à£‚à£Œº‚àíy‚àíN‚àí2Sy‚à£‚à£2]=...=NœÑ2œÑ2+1+2œÑ2+1R(\mu,\hat{\mu}^{(JS)})=E_{\mu}[||\mu-\hat{\mu}^{(JS)}||^2]=E_{\mu}[||\mu-y-\frac{N-2}{S}y||^2]\\=...\\=N\frac{\tau^2}{\tau^2+1}+\frac{2}{\tau^2+1}R(Œº,Œº^‚Äã(JS))=EŒº‚Äã[‚à£‚à£Œº‚àíŒº^‚Äã(JS)‚à£‚à£2]=EŒº‚Äã[‚à£‚à£Œº‚àíy‚àíSN‚àí2‚Äãy‚à£‚à£2]=...=NœÑ2+1œÑ2‚Äã+œÑ2+12‚ÄãÔªø‚Äã
This is larger than the Bayesian risk, found in 1.1, and we have
RÀâ(JS)RÀâ=1+2NœÑ2\frac{\bar{R}^{(JS)}}{\bar{R}}=1+\frac{2}{N\tau^2}RÀâRÀâ(JS)‚Äã=1+NœÑ22‚ÄãÔªø‚Äã
Thus JS very similar to Bayes estimator when N is large.
The proof also show that
R(Œº,Œº^(JS))=N‚àíEŒº[(N‚àí2)2S]R(\mu,\hat{\mu}^{(JS)})=N-E_\mu[\frac{(N-2)^2}{S}]R(Œº,Œº^‚Äã(JS))=N‚àíEŒº‚Äã[S(N‚àí2)2‚Äã]Ôªø‚Äã
So the JS estimator dominates the MLE if N‚ÄÑ‚â•‚ÄÑ2.
See the full proof here.
So why one would use the MLE is high-dimension? Because:
The JS estimator is biased, since the MLE is the minimum variance unbiased estimator (Rao-Blackwell theorem). So the JS reduces its variance but adds bias: good for point estimation but challenging for frequentist interval estimation.
The MLE is admissible in 1 and 2-dimensions, but even in higher dimensions, if we focus on a single ‚Äúoutlier‚Äù entry, the MLE has a better MSE (see why below).
In high dimension, suppose we generate values from
yi‚ÄÖ‚Ää‚àº‚ÄÖ‚ÄäN(Œºi,1)‚ÄÖ‚Ääfor‚ÄÖ‚Ääi=1,...,11y_i\;\sim\;N(\mu_i,1)\;for\;i=1,...,11yi‚Äã‚àºN(Œºi‚Äã,1)fori=1,...,11Ôªø‚Äã
We put
Œºi=(5,‚àí1,‚àí0.75,...,0.75,1)\mu_i=(5,-1,-0.75,...,0.75,1)Œºi‚Äã=(5,‚àí1,‚àí0.75,...,0.75,1)Ôªø‚Äã
For each simulation replicate, we estimate Œº by the MLE and by JS. We find:

1-4 Full Bayes inference

We could conclude at this point that one should always use empirical Bayes to choose a prior. However, when it comes to estimating a parameter, the Bayesian approach is to put a prior on it.
Thus if our problem is
y‚ÄÖ‚Ää‚àº‚ÄÖ‚ÄäN(Œº,I)Œº‚ÄÖ‚Ää‚àº‚ÄÖ‚ÄäN(0,œÑ2I)œÑ2‚ÄÖ‚Ää‚àº‚ÄÖ‚Ääp(œÑ2)y\;\sim\;N(\mu,I)\\\mu\;\sim\;N(0,\tau^2I)\\\tau^2\;\sim\;p(\tau^2)y‚àºN(Œº,I)Œº‚àºN(0,œÑ2I)œÑ2‚àºp(œÑ2)Ôªø‚Äã
now our problem is to estimate p(œÑ2)p(\tau^2)p(œÑ2)Ôªø. Since we want to estimate œÑ2\tau^2œÑ2Ôªø from our data, we have to place an objective prior on œÑ2\tau^2œÑ2Ôªø: p(œÑ2)=1p(œÑ^2)=1p(œÑ2)=1Ôªø‚Äã
So we compute the posterior of Œº to find out that its posterior expectation is challenging to evaluate, although our initial model is simple.
We now have:
y‚ÄÖ‚Ää‚àº‚ÄÖ‚ÄäN(Œº,I)Œº‚ÄÖ‚Ää‚àº‚ÄÖ‚ÄäN(0,œÑ2I)œÑ2‚ÄÖ‚Ää‚àº‚ÄÖ‚Ääp(œÑ2)=1y\;\sim\;N(\mu,I)\\\mu\;\sim\;N(0,\tau^2I)\\\tau^2\;\sim\;p(\tau^2)=1y‚àºN(Œº,I)Œº‚àºN(0,œÑ2I)œÑ2‚àºp(œÑ2)=1Ôªø‚Äã
Let‚Äôs compute the posterior
p(Œº,œÑ2‚à£y)‚àùp(y‚à£Œº)p(Œº‚à£œÑ2)p(œÑ2)=(2œÄ)‚àíNe‚àí12(y‚àíŒº)‚Ä≤I(y‚àíŒº)(œÑ2)‚àíN/2e‚àí12Œº‚Ä≤(œÑ2I)‚àí1Œº=(2œÄ)‚àíN(œÑ2)‚àíN/2e‚àí12(Œº‚àí(1+œÑ‚àí2)‚àí1y)‚Ä≤(1+œÑ‚àí2)I(Œº‚àí(1+œÑ‚àí2)‚àí1y)e‚àí12y‚Ä≤(1‚àí(1+œÑ2)‚àí1Iy)p(\mu,\tau^2|y)\propto p(y|\mu)p(\mu|\tau^2)p(\tau^2) = (2\pi)^{-N}e^{-\frac{1}{2}(y-\mu)'I(y-\mu)}(\tau^2)^{-N/2}e^{-\frac{1}{2}\mu'(\tau^2I)^{-1}\mu}\\=(2\pi)^{-N}(\tau^2)^{-N/2}e^{-\frac{1}{2}(\mu-(1+\tau^{-2})^{-1}y)'(1+\tau^{-2})I(\mu-(1+\tau^{-2})^{-1}y)}e^{-\frac{1}{2}y'(1-(1+\tau^2)^{-1}Iy)}p(Œº,œÑ2‚à£y)‚àùp(y‚à£Œº)p(Œº‚à£œÑ2)p(œÑ2)=(2œÄ)‚àíNe‚àí21‚Äã(y‚àíŒº)‚Ä≤I(y‚àíŒº)(œÑ2)‚àíN/2e‚àí21‚ÄãŒº‚Ä≤(œÑ2I)‚àí1Œº=(2œÄ)‚àíN(œÑ2)‚àíN/2e‚àí21‚Äã(Œº‚àí(1+œÑ‚àí2)‚àí1y)‚Ä≤(1+œÑ‚àí2)I(Œº‚àí(1+œÑ‚àí2)‚àí1y)e‚àí21‚Äãy‚Ä≤(1‚àí(1+œÑ2)‚àí1Iy)Ôªø‚Äã
I spare you the lengthy proof of this result, which would need an article in itself.
We need some alternative way to do integration that doesn‚Äôt involve actually computing all of the integrals analytically.

2. Markov Chain & Monte Carlo

We still have the same problem. Now we know that getting the posterior is hard if we can‚Äôt find the normalising constant through some known distribution.
Another choice is the half Cauchy prior on œÑ
p(œÑ)‚àù11+œÑ2p(\tau)\propto\frac{1}{1+\tau^2}p(œÑ)‚àù1+œÑ21‚ÄãÔªø‚Äã
We choose to have an Inverse Gamma prior on œÑ2\tau^2œÑ2Ôªø and a Normal prior on mmmÔªø.
We show that computing the posterior become very ugly
The half Cauchy prior is not a conjugate prior, so now we consider:
y‚ÄÖ‚Ää‚àº‚ÄÖ‚ÄäN(Œº,œÉ2I)Œº‚ÄÖ‚Ää‚àº‚ÄÖ‚ÄäN(m,œÉ2œÑ2I)p(œÑ)‚àù11+œÑ2y\;\sim\;N(\mu,\sigma^2I)\\\mu\;\sim\;N(m,\sigma^2\tau^2I)\\p(\tau)\propto\frac{1}{1+\tau^2}y‚àºN(Œº,œÉ2I)Œº‚àºN(m,œÉ2œÑ2I)p(œÑ)‚àù1+œÑ21‚ÄãÔªø‚Äã
The posterior can be written
p(m,œÑ2,œÉ2,Œº‚à£y)‚àùp(y‚à£Œº,œÉ2)p(Œº‚à£œÉ2,œÑ2,m)p(œÉ2)p(œÑ2)p(m)p(m,\tau^2,\sigma^2,\mu|y)\propto p(y|\mu,\sigma^2)p(\mu|\sigma^2,\tau^2,m)p(\sigma^2)p(\tau^2)p(m)p(m,œÑ2,œÉ2,Œº‚à£y)‚àùp(y‚à£Œº,œÉ2)p(Œº‚à£œÉ2,œÑ2,m)p(œÉ2)p(œÑ2)p(m)Ôªø‚Äã
We try to find the normalizing constant p(y)p(y)p(y)Ôªø:
‚à´‚à£2œÄœÉ2I‚à£‚àí1/2e‚àí12(y‚àíŒº)T(œÉ2I)‚àí1(y‚àíŒº)‚à£2œÄœÉ2œÑ2I‚àí1/2‚à£e‚àí12(Œº‚àím)T(œÉ2œÑ2I)‚àí1(y‚àím)dŒº=(2œÄœÉ2)‚àíN/2(œÑ2)‚àíN/2e(y‚àím‚àó)(Œ£‚àó)‚àí1(y‚àím‚àó)\int|2\pi\sigma^2I|^{-1/2}e^{-\frac{1}{2}(y-\mu)^T(\sigma^2I)^{-1}(y-\mu)}|2\pi\sigma^2\tau^2I^{-1/2}|e^{-\frac{1}{2}(\mu-m)^T(\sigma^2\tau^2I)^{-1}(y-m)}d\mu\\=(2\pi\sigma^2)^{-N/2}(\tau^2)^{-N/2}e^{(y-m^*)(\Sigma^*)^{-1}(y-m^*)}‚à´‚à£2œÄœÉ2I‚à£‚àí1/2e‚àí21‚Äã(y‚àíŒº)T(œÉ2I)‚àí1(y‚àíŒº)‚à£2œÄœÉ2œÑ2I‚àí1/2‚à£e‚àí21‚Äã(Œº‚àím)T(œÉ2œÑ2I)‚àí1(y‚àím)dŒº=(2œÄœÉ2)‚àíN/2(œÑ2)‚àíN/2e(y‚àím‚àó)(Œ£‚àó)‚àí1(y‚àím‚àó)Ôªø‚Äã
However, in high-dimensions we don‚Äôt really care about the whole posterior, but more about some functional of it, like the posterior expectations of a function f:
‚à´f(Œ∏)p(y‚à£Œ∏)p(Œ∏)p(y)dŒ∏\int\frac{f(\theta)p(y|\theta)p(\theta)}{p(y)}d\theta‚à´p(y)f(Œ∏)p(y‚à£Œ∏)p(Œ∏)‚ÄãdŒ∏Ôªø‚Äã
It turns out this integral can be approximated using Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC). It consists in sampling the desired distribution by recording states from the Markov chain, which has the desired distribution as its equilibrium distribution.
Let‚Äôs see the difference with ordinary Monte Carlo.
Suppose we have Y‚àºGY \sim GY‚àºGÔªø and we want to compute the quantity E[log(Y)]\mathbb{E}[log(Y)]E[log(Y)]Ôªø‚Äã
One idea in to take samples from g(Œ∏), say
Œ∏1,...,Œ∏N‚ÄÖ‚Ää‚àºiid‚ÄÖ‚ÄäG\theta_1,..., \theta_N\;\sim^{iid}\;GŒ∏1‚Äã,...,Œ∏N‚Äã‚àºiidGÔªø‚Äã
and then use
E[log‚ÄâY]undefined=1n‚àëj=0n‚àí1log(Œ∏j)\widehat{\mathbb{E}[log\,Y]}=\frac{1}{n}\sum^{n-1}_{j=0}log(\theta_j)E[logY]‚Äã=n1‚Äã‚àëj=0n‚àí1‚Äãlog(Œ∏j‚Äã)Ôªø‚Äã
If we could sample Y‚ÄÑ‚àº‚ÄÑG, it would be just ordinary Monte Carlo.
A Markov chain is a sequence of random variable ignoring the whole history (independent) except for the last event:
p(XN‚à£X0,...,XN‚àí1)=p(XN‚à£XN‚àí1)p(X_N|X_0,...,X_{N-1})=p(X_N|X_{N-1})p(XN‚Äã‚à£X0‚Äã,...,XN‚àí1‚Äã)=p(XN‚Äã‚à£XN‚àí1‚Äã)Ôªø‚Äã
We hop from one state nnnÔªø to state n+1n+1n+1Ôªø via a transition kernel KKKÔªø. Some KKKÔªø have invariant distribution.
Let‚Äôs see how it suggests the Gibs sampling model to construct K.
Xn‚àà{0,1}‚ÄÖ‚Ääand‚ÄÖ‚ÄäŒ±,Œ≤‚àà[0,1]Xn‚à£(Xn‚àí1=0)={0‚ÄÖ‚Ääwith‚ÄÖ‚Ääproba‚ÄÖ‚Ää1‚àíŒ±1‚ÄÖ‚Ääwith‚ÄÖ‚Ääproba‚ÄÖ‚ÄäŒ±Xn‚à£(Xn‚àí1=1)={0‚ÄÖ‚Ääwith‚ÄÖ‚Ääproba‚ÄÖ‚ÄäŒ≤1‚ÄÖ‚Ääwith‚ÄÖ‚Ääproba‚ÄÖ‚Ää1‚àíŒ≤X_n\in\{0,1\}\;and\;\alpha,\beta\in[0,1]\\X_n|(X_{n-1}=0)= \Bigg\{ \begin{array}{ll}0\;with\;proba\;1-\alpha \\ 1\;with\;proba\;\alpha \end{array}\\X_n|(X_{n-1}=1)= \Bigg\{ \begin{array}{ll}0\;with\;proba\;\beta \\ 1\;with\;proba\;1-\beta \end{array}Xn‚Äã‚àà{0,1}andŒ±,Œ≤‚àà[0,1]Xn‚Äã‚à£(Xn‚àí1‚Äã=0)={0withproba1‚àíŒ±1withprobaŒ±‚ÄãXn‚Äã‚à£(Xn‚àí1‚Äã=1)={0withprobaŒ≤1withproba1‚àíŒ≤‚ÄãÔªø‚Äã
so our transition matrix K is
K=[1‚àíŒ±Œ±Œ≤1‚àíŒ≤]K=\Bigg[ \begin{array}{cc}1-\alpha & \alpha\\ \beta & 1-\beta \end{array} \Bigg]K=[1‚àíŒ±Œ≤‚ÄãŒ±1‚àíŒ≤‚Äã]Ôªø‚Äã
In high dimension, K is no longer a matrix but an operator mapping function. This way, the density
X1‚à£X0‚ÄÖ‚Ää‚àº‚ÄÖ‚ÄäPX_1|X_0\;\sim\;PX1‚Äã‚à£X0‚Äã‚àºPÔªø‚Äã
can be written
‚à´p(x)k(x,y)dx=pÀâ(y)\int p(x)k(x,y)dx=\bar{p}(y)‚à´p(x)k(x,y)dx=pÀâ‚Äã(y)Ôªø‚Äã
How can we use Markov Chain to compute expectations with respect to the posterior?
Some K have an invariant distribution: ŒºK=Œº\mu K=\muŒºK=ŒºÔªø‚Äã
If Œº\muŒºÔªø has density pppÔªø, this means
‚à´p(x)k(x,y)dx=p(y)\int p(x)k(x,y)dx=p(y)‚à´p(x)k(x,y)dx=p(y)Ôªø‚Äã
If the invariant measure ŒºŒºŒºÔªø exists and is unique then:
lim‚Å°n‚Üí‚àûŒΩKn=Œº\lim_{n \rightarrow \infty}\nu K^n=\mulimn‚Üí‚àû‚ÄãŒΩKn=ŒºÔªø‚Äã
If we start at the state ŒΩ, the distribution will look more and more like the invariant distribution.
Thus if we could make the posterior our invariant distribution, we could sample from it using Markov chains:
if‚ÄÖ‚ÄäX0‚ÄÖ‚Ää‚àº‚ÄÖ‚ÄäŒΩ‚ÄÖ‚Ääand‚ÄÖ‚ÄäXn‚à£Xn‚àí1‚ÄÖ‚Ää‚àº‚ÄÖ‚ÄäK(Xn‚àí1,.)\;X_0\;\sim\;\nu\;and\;X_n|X_{n-1}\;\sim\;K(X_{n-1},.)X0‚Äã‚àºŒΩandXn‚Äã‚à£Xn‚àí1‚Äã‚àºK(Xn‚àí1‚Äã,.)Ôªø,
then 1n‚àëk=0n‚àí1œï(Xk)‚Üín‚Üí‚àû‚ÄÖ‚Ääi.p.‚à´œï(x)p(x)dx\frac{1}{n}\sum^{n-1}_{k=0}\phi(X_k)\rightarrow^{n\rightarrow\infty\;i.p.}\int\phi(x)p(x)dxn1‚Äã‚àëk=0n‚àí1‚Äãœï(Xk‚Äã)‚Üín‚Üí‚àûi.p.‚à´œï(x)p(x)dxÔªø‚Äã
if KKKÔªø has invariant density pppÔªø. That means the empirical averages converge to expected value we are looking for.

2.1 Gibbs sampling

We want to construct KKKÔªø for arbitrary distributions. We need to compute the posterior without knowing the normalising constant p(y)p(y)p(y)Ôªø.
In Gibbs sampling the idea is to break the problem of sampling from the high-dimensional joint distribution into a series of samples from low-dimensional conditional distributions.
We illustrate the algorithm here
Find a KKKÔªø with invariant distribution p(Œ∏‚à£y)p(Œ∏|y)p(Œ∏‚à£y)Ôªø.
Start somewhere X0‚ÄÑ‚àº‚ÄÑŒΩX_0‚ÄÑ‚àº‚ÄÑŒΩX0‚Äã‚ÄÑ‚àº‚ÄÑŒΩÔªø.
Simulate forward a lot of steps.
Throw out B steps (burn-in, intermediary steps, far from the convergence).
Average the rest.
Here steps 1 to 3 look like this:

2.2 Metropolis-Hastings algorithm

If one of the Gibbs conditionals is not conjugate, a Metropolis-Hasting step is used in the Gibbs iteration.
Here is an implementation: MCMC sampling for dummies
This new step ensure the transition kernel is reversible, which guarantee that the Markov chain converges to the correct invariant measure.
The core idea is to compute an acceptance ratio, which is the probability to jump to the next step.
We illustrates the algorithm here with an example and a measure of MSE to assess the quality of convergence.
Suppose we want to sample from a density f(x,a)M(a)f(x, a)M(a)f(x,a)M(a)Ôªø, with M(a)M(a)M(a)Ôªø normalising constant
Choose a proposal Q(x,‚ÄÜ.)Q(x,‚ÄÜ.)Q(x,‚ÄÜ.)Ôªø with density q(x,‚ÄÜy)q(x,‚ÄÜy)q(x,‚ÄÜy)Ôªø. For exemple y‚ÄÑ‚àº‚ÄÑN(x,‚ÄÜs)y‚ÄÑ‚àº‚ÄÑN(x,‚ÄÜs)y‚ÄÑ‚àº‚ÄÑN(x,‚ÄÜs)Ôªø‚Äã
At state nnnÔªø, propose new state:
Xn‚àó‚ÄÖ‚Ää‚àº‚ÄÖ‚ÄäQ(Xn‚àí1,.)X_n^*\;\sim\;Q(X_{n-1},.)Xn‚àó‚Äã‚àºQ(Xn‚àí1‚Äã,.)Ôªø‚Äã
Compute the acceptance ratio:
Œ±(Xn‚àí1,Xn‚àó)=min(1,f(Xn‚àó,a)q(Xn‚àó‚à£Xn‚àí1)f(Xn‚àí1,a)q(Xn‚àí1‚à£Xn‚àó))\alpha(X_{n-1},X_n^*)=min\bigg(1, \frac{f(X_n^*,a)q(X^*_n|X_{n-1})}{f(X_{n-1},a)q(X_{n-1}|X_n^*)}\bigg)Œ±(Xn‚àí1‚Äã,Xn‚àó‚Äã)=min(1,f(Xn‚àí1‚Äã,a)q(Xn‚àí1‚Äã‚à£Xn‚àó‚Äã)f(Xn‚àó‚Äã,a)q(Xn‚àó‚Äã‚à£Xn‚àí1‚Äã)‚Äã)Ôªø‚Äã
With probability Œ±\alphaŒ±Ôªø, Xn=Xn‚àóX_n=X_n^*Xn‚Äã=Xn‚àó‚ÄãÔªø, otherwise Xn=Xn‚àí1X_n=X_{n-1}Xn‚Äã=Xn‚àí1‚ÄãÔªø with proba 1‚àíŒ±1-\alpha1‚àíŒ±Ôªø‚Äã
If we take the model:

the only parameter is œÑœÑœÑÔªø, so:

We know that:

If we start at ŒΩ‚ÄÑ=‚ÄÑŒº, then the bias would be 0 but not the covariance.

We can diagnosis convergence via:

2.2.a Asymptotic variance

The Effective sample size (ESS) allows us to estimate œÉ, thanks to the Central Limit Theorem.
We have:
n[1n‚àëj=0n‚àí1œï(Xj)‚àíŒºœï]‚áíN(0,œÉ2)\sqrt{n}\bigg[\frac{1}{n}\sum^{n-1}_{j=0}\phi(X_j)-\mu\phi\bigg]\Rightarrow N(0,\sigma^2)n‚Äã[n1‚Äã‚àëj=0n‚àí1‚Äãœï(Xj‚Äã)‚àíŒºœï]‚áíN(0,œÉ2)Ôªø‚Äã

œÉ2=V[X0]‚àëj=0‚àûCorr(X0,Xj)\sigma^2=\mathbb{V}[X_0]\sum^{\infty}_{j=0}Corr(X_0,X_j)œÉ2=V[X0‚Äã]‚àëj=0‚àû‚ÄãCorr(X0‚Äã,Xj‚Äã)Ôªø‚Äã
We want to estimate œÉ2œÉ^2œÉ2Ôªø.
For batches bn‚ÄÑ=‚ÄÑn1/3b_n‚ÄÑ=‚ÄÑn^{1/3}bn‚Äã‚ÄÑ=‚ÄÑn1/3Ôªø there are n‚ÄÖ‚àí‚ÄÖbnn‚ÄÖ‚àí‚ÄÖb_nn‚ÄÖ‚àí‚ÄÖbn‚ÄãÔªø such batches and
œÉ2^=(n‚àí1)bn(n‚àíbn)(n‚àíbn‚àí1)‚àëj=0n‚àíbn‚àí1(XÀâj(bn)‚àíXÀân)\hat{\sigma^2}=\frac{(n-1)b_n}{(n-b_n)(n-b_n-1)}\sum^{n-b_n-1}_{j=0}(\bar{X}_j(b_n)-\bar{X}_n)œÉ2^=(n‚àíbn‚Äã)(n‚àíbn‚Äã‚àí1)(n‚àí1)bn‚Äã‚Äã‚àëj=0n‚àíbn‚Äã‚àí1‚Äã(XÀâj‚Äã(bn‚Äã)‚àíXÀân‚Äã)Ôªø‚Äã

2.2.b Plotting Autocorrelation

We plot the autocorrelation of the chain, ideally quickly decreasing to zero (the chain itself looks like white noise).
Let‚Äôs see how to use Gibb sampling to compute conditional mean and variance.
Suppose we are interested in sampling

2.2.c Comparison

We run multiple choices and compare them using the Gelman-Rubin diagnostic.
The Gelman-Rubin diagnostic is:
run mmmÔªø chains of length 2n2n2nÔªø, starting over dispersed points, discard first nnnÔªø‚Äã
compute the between variance:
Bn=‚àëi=1m(xÀâi‚àíxÀâ)2n‚àí1\frac{B}{n}=\sum^m_{i=1}\frac{(\bar{x}_i-\bar{x})^2}{n-1}nB‚Äã=‚àëi=1m‚Äãn‚àí1(xÀâi‚Äã‚àíxÀâ)2‚ÄãÔªø‚Äã
and the within variance
W=1m‚àëi=1m(1n‚àí1‚àëj=1nxij‚àíxÀâi)2W=\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i=1}^m \bigg(\frac{1}{n-1}\sum^n_{j=1}x_{ij}-\bar{x}_i\bigg)^2W=m1‚Äã‚àëi=1m‚Äã(n‚àí11‚Äã‚àëj=1n‚Äãxij‚Äã‚àíxÀâi‚Äã)2Ôªø‚Äã
and take the estimated variance to be
œÉ^+2=n‚àí1nW+Bn\hat{\sigma}^2_+=\frac{n-1}{n}W+\frac{B}{n}œÉ^+2‚Äã=nn‚àí1‚ÄãW+nB‚ÄãÔªø‚Äã
However the shortcomings of this idea is to only consider the effect of auto-correlations for the identity function.
We need to bound autocorrelations for a huge class of functions if we want to converge in total variation

2.2.d Coupling

We run m pairs of chains to simulate two dependent Markov chains, and run the chains until they meet
We have: (X,Y)‚àºŒì(ŒΩ0,ŒΩ1)(X,Y)\sim\Gamma(\nu_0,\nu_1)(X,Y)‚àºŒì(ŒΩ0‚Äã,ŒΩ1‚Äã)Ôªø‚Äã
so that marginally
X‚àºŒΩ0‚ÄÖ‚Ääand‚ÄÖ‚ÄäY‚àºŒΩ1X\sim\nu_0\;and\;Y\sim\nu_1X‚àºŒΩ0‚ÄãandY‚àºŒΩ1‚ÄãÔªø‚Äã
We define the total variation metric between distributions:
‚à£‚à£ŒΩ0‚àíŒΩ1‚à£‚à£TV=supA‚à£ŒΩ0(A)‚àíŒΩ1(A)‚à£||\nu_0-\nu_1||_{TV}=sup_A|\nu_0(A)-\nu_1(A)|‚à£‚à£ŒΩ0‚Äã‚àíŒΩ1‚Äã‚à£‚à£TV‚Äã=supA‚Äã‚à£ŒΩ0‚Äã(A)‚àíŒΩ1‚Äã(A)‚à£Ôªø‚Äã
The coupling inequality states that
P[X‚â†Y]‚â•‚à£‚à£ŒΩ0‚àíŒΩ1‚à£‚à£TVP[X \neq Y]\geq||\nu_0-\nu_1||_{TV}P[XÓÄ†=Y]‚â•‚à£‚à£ŒΩ0‚Äã‚àíŒΩ1‚Äã‚à£‚à£TV‚ÄãÔªø‚Äã
Thus the idea is to simulate from two dependent Markov chains at different points
Xn‚àºŒΩ0Kn‚ÄÖ‚Ääand‚ÄÖ‚ÄäYn‚àºŒΩ1KnX_n\sim\nu_0K^n\;and\;Y_n\sim\nu_1K^nXn‚Äã‚àºŒΩ0‚ÄãKnandYn‚Äã‚àºŒΩ1‚ÄãKnÔªø‚Äã
and run the chain until they meet
For exemple take:
X‚àºfW‚à£X‚àºU(0,f(X))X\sim f \\W|X\sim U(0,f(X))X‚àºfW‚à£X‚àºU(0,f(X))Ôªø‚Äã
if W<g(X)W < g(X)W<g(X)Ôªø output (X,X)(X, X)(X,X)Ôªø‚Äã
else sample Y‚àó‚àºgY^* \sim gY‚àó‚àºgÔªø and take W‚àó‚à£Y‚àó‚àºU(0,‚ÄÜg(Y‚àó))W^*|Y^*\sim U(0,‚ÄÜg(Y^*))W‚àó‚à£Y‚àó‚àºU(0,‚ÄÜg(Y‚àó))Ôªø until W‚àó‚ÄÑ>‚ÄÑf(Y‚àó)W^*‚ÄÑ>‚ÄÑf(Y^*)W‚àó‚ÄÑ>‚ÄÑf(Y‚àó)Ôªø and output (X,‚ÄÜY‚àó)(X,‚ÄÜY^*)(X,‚ÄÜY‚àó)Ôªø‚Äã

3. Nontrivial models

3.1 Linear regression

We see how Bayesian linear regression
zN√ó1=WN√ódŒ≤d√ó1+œµN√ó1with‚ÄÖ‚Ääœµ‚àºN(0,œÉ2I)z_{N√ó1}=W_{N√ód}\beta_{d√ó1}+\epsilon_{N√ó1}\\with\;\epsilon\sim N(0,\sigma^2I)zN√ó1‚Äã=WN√ód‚ÄãŒ≤d√ó1‚Äã+œµN√ó1‚Äãwithœµ‚àºN(0,œÉ2I)Ôªø‚Äã
easily leads to ridge estimate
Œ≤^ridge=E[Œ≤‚à£W,œÉ2,z,œÑ2]=(WTW+1œÑ2I)‚àí1WTz\hat{\beta}_{ridge}=\mathbb{E}[\beta|W,\sigma^2,z,\tau^2]=\Big(W^TW+\frac{1}{\tau^2}I\Big)^{-1}W^TzŒ≤^‚Äãridge‚Äã=E[Œ≤‚à£W,œÉ2,z,œÑ2]=(WTW+œÑ21‚ÄãI)‚àí1WTzÔªø‚Äã
where z is the response, W is the matrix, Œ≤ is the vector of regression coefficients, and œµ is the vector of random error.
The usual least square estimate is
Œ≤^OLS=(WTW)‚àí1WTz\hat{\beta}_{OLS}=(W^TW)^{-1}W^TzŒ≤^‚ÄãOLS‚Äã=(WTW)‚àí1WTzÔªø‚Äã
which is also the MLE for Œ≤. The MLE for œÉ2 is given by
œÉ^2=1N(Z‚àíWŒ≤^)T(Z‚àíWŒ≤^)=‚à£‚à£zT(Id‚àíW(WTW)‚àí1WT)z‚à£‚à£2\hat{\sigma}^2=\frac{1}{N}(Z-W\hat{\beta})^T(Z-W\hat{\beta})=||z^T(I_d-W(W^TW)^{-1}W^T)z||^2œÉ^2=N1‚Äã(Z‚àíWŒ≤^‚Äã)T(Z‚àíWŒ≤^‚Äã)=‚à£‚à£zT(Id‚Äã‚àíW(WTW)‚àí1WT)z‚à£‚à£2Ôªø‚Äã
These work fine when N‚ÄÑ>>‚ÄÑd, but if d is big, using shrinkage make sense. So we consider the Bayesian hierarchical model
z‚àºN(WŒ≤,œÉ2)Œ≤‚àºN(0,œÑ2œÉ2I)z\sim N(W\beta,\sigma^2)\\\beta\sim N(0,\tau^2\sigma^2I)z‚àºN(WŒ≤,œÉ2)Œ≤‚àºN(0,œÑ2œÉ2I)Ôªø‚Äã
Thus, we have
‚àí2log(L(z‚à£Œ≤,w,œÉ2)p(Œ≤))‚àù1œÉ2(z‚àíWŒ≤T)(z‚àíWŒ≤)+1œÉ2œÑ2Œ≤TŒ≤‚àùŒ≤T[1œÉ2WTW+1œÉ2œÑ2I]‚àí2Œ≤T(WTzœÉ2)-2log(L(z|\beta,w,\sigma^2)p(\beta))\propto \frac{1}{\sigma^2}(z-W\beta^T)(z-W\beta)+\frac{1}{\sigma^2\tau^2}\beta^T\beta\\\propto\beta^T\Big[\frac{1}{\sigma^2}W^TW+\frac{1}{\sigma^2\tau^2}I\Big]-2\beta^T\Big(\frac{W^Tz}{\sigma^2}\Big)‚àí2log(L(z‚à£Œ≤,w,œÉ2)p(Œ≤))‚àùœÉ21‚Äã(z‚àíWŒ≤T)(z‚àíWŒ≤)+œÉ2œÑ21‚ÄãŒ≤TŒ≤‚àùŒ≤T[œÉ21‚ÄãWTW+œÉ2œÑ21‚ÄãI]‚àí2Œ≤T(œÉ2WTz‚Äã)Ôªø‚Äã
so
Œ≤‚à£W,œÉ2,œÑ2‚àºN(VŒº‚àó,V)\beta|W,\sigma^2,\tau^2\sim N(V\mu^*,V)Œ≤‚à£W,œÉ2,œÑ2‚àºN(VŒº‚àó,V)Ôªø‚Äã
with
V=(1œÉ2WTW+1œÉ2œÑ2I)‚àí1Œº‚àó=1œÉ2WTzV = \Big(\frac{1}{\sigma^2}W^TW+\frac{1}{\sigma^2\tau^2I}\Big)^{-1} \\ \mu^*=\frac{1}{\sigma^2}W^TzV=(œÉ21‚ÄãWTW+œÉ2œÑ2I1‚Äã)‚àí1Œº‚àó=œÉ21‚ÄãWTzÔªø‚Äã
Thus the posterior mean is:
Œ≤^ridge=E[Œ≤‚à£W,œÉ2,z,œÑ2]=VŒº‚àó=(WTW+1œÑ2I)‚àí1WTz\hat{\beta}_{ridge}=\mathbb{E}[\beta|W,\sigma^2,z,\tau^2]=V\mu^*=\Big(W^TW+\frac{1}{\tau^2}I\Big)^{-1}W^TzŒ≤^‚Äãridge‚Äã=E[Œ≤‚à£W,œÉ2,z,œÑ2]=VŒº‚àó=(WTW+œÑ21‚ÄãI)‚àí1WTzÔªø‚Äã
This is the usual ridge regression estimate, which solves
Œ≤^ridge=maxŒ≤‚àí‚à£‚à£WŒ≤‚àíz‚à£‚à£2‚àíœÑ‚àí2‚à£‚à£Œ≤‚à£‚à£2\hat{\beta}_{ridge}=max_{\beta}-||W\beta-z||^2-\tau^{-2}||\beta||^2Œ≤^‚Äãridge‚Äã=maxŒ≤‚Äã‚àí‚à£‚à£WŒ≤‚àíz‚à£‚à£2‚àíœÑ‚àí2‚à£‚à£Œ≤‚à£‚à£2Ôªø‚Äã

3.2 Tikhonov regularisation

More generally we have Tikhonov regularization
Œ≤^ridge=(WTW+A‚àí1)‚àí1WTz\hat{\beta}_{ridge}=(W^TW+A^{-1})^{-1}W^TzŒ≤^‚Äãridge‚Äã=(WTW+A‚àí1)‚àí1WTzÔªø‚Äã
where A symmetric, positive definite.
We regularise because:
Adding a bias may improve our estimation of a vector with more than 2 dimensions (see JS estimator)
When p‚ÄÑ>‚ÄÑN, least square can‚Äôt be done, but regularised solution can
We see in that its much harder to get A with Empirical Bayes than Full Bayes (in particular when Œ≤ doesn‚Äôt follow a Normal distribution).
We maximise the marginal likelihood (in term of œÑ2\tau^2œÑ2Ôªø)
Pick a prior structure:
Œ≤‚à£œÉ2,œÑ2‚àºN(0,œÉ2œÑ2I)œÉ2‚àºInvGamma(a,b)\beta|\sigma^2,\tau^2\sim N(0,\sigma^2\tau^2I)\\\sigma^2\sim InvGamma(a,b)Œ≤‚à£œÉ2,œÑ2‚àºN(0,œÉ2œÑ2I)œÉ2‚àºInvGamma(a,b)Ôªø‚Äã
which can be reframed Œ≤‚àºN(0,œÉ2œÑ2I)Z‚àºN(WŒ≤,œÉ2I)\beta\sim N(0,\sigma^2\tau^2I)\\Z\sim N(W\beta,\sigma^2I)Œ≤‚àºN(0,œÉ2œÑ2I)Z‚àºN(WŒ≤,œÉ2I)Ôªø‚Äã
so:
Z‚àºN(0,œÉ2(œÑ‚àí2WWT+I))Z\sim N(0,\sigma^2(\tau^{-2}WW^T+I))Z‚àºN(0,œÉ2(œÑ‚àí2WWT+I))Ôªø‚Äã
We compute easily the likelihood: p(z‚à£œÉ2œÑ2,W)p(z|\sigma^2\tau^2,W)p(z‚à£œÉ2œÑ2,W)Ôªø‚Äã
Now we just need to multiply by the prior density for œÉ2\sigma^2œÉ2Ôªø and integrate over œÉ2\sigma^2œÉ2Ôªø. This is easy since the function is the kernel of an inverse-gamma distribution.
Then we pick œÑ\tauœÑÔªø according to: maxœÑ2‚à´p(z‚à£W,œÉ2,Œ≤,œÑ2)p(Œ≤,œÉ2)dŒ≤dœÉ2max_{\tau^2}\int p(z|W,\sigma^2,\beta,\tau^2)p(\beta,\sigma^2)d\beta d\sigma^2maxœÑ2‚Äã‚à´p(z‚à£W,œÉ2,Œ≤,œÑ2)p(Œ≤,œÉ2)dŒ≤dœÉ2Ôªø‚Äã
If Œ≤\betaŒ≤Ôªø were not coming from a Normal distribution, this problem could quickly become intractable (above all because Œ≤\betaŒ≤Ôªø is high-dimensional).
Full Bayes To estimate A, we put a prior on œÑ . What possibilities?
Discrete Uniform on a set of grid points
Uniform on an interval
Half-Cauchy
Inverse Gamma
We use Half-Cauchy: it requires no hyperparameters and it is reasonably uninformative (it let the data speak for itself). The full model is:
Œ≤‚à£œÉ2,œÑ2‚àºN(0,œÉ2œÑ2I)œÉ2‚àºInvGamma(a,b)p(œÑ)‚àº12œÄ11+œÑ2\beta|\sigma^2,\tau^2\sim N(0, \sigma^2\tau^2I)\\\sigma^2\sim InvGamma(a,b)\\p(\tau)\sim \frac{1}{2\pi}\frac{1}{1+\tau^2}Œ≤‚à£œÉ2,œÑ2‚àºN(0,œÉ2œÑ2I)œÉ2‚àºInvGamma(a,b)p(œÑ)‚àº2œÄ1‚Äã1+œÑ21‚ÄãÔªø‚Äã
This can be done using Gibbs sampling
Œ≤‚à£œÑ2,œÉ2,W,zœÉ2‚à£œÑ2,Œ≤,W,zœÑ2‚à£œÉ2,Œ≤2\beta|\tau^2,\sigma^2,W,z\\\sigma^2|\tau^2,\beta,W,z\\\tau^2|\sigma^2,\beta^2Œ≤‚à£œÑ2,œÉ2,W,zœÉ2‚à£œÑ2,Œ≤,W,zœÑ2‚à£œÉ2,Œ≤2Ôªø‚Äã
The first two distribution are easy to sample from. The third distribution is well known and we can directly sample it with Metropolis-Hastings

3.3 Conjugate prior

Another option to solve Bayesian linear regression is using a conjugate prior.
We see how Zellner‚Äôs g prior gives us a posterior with a mean that is a shrunken factor of the MLE.
We have:
Œ≤,œÉ2‚àºNŒì‚àí1(Œº,V,a,b)\beta,\sigma^2\sim N\Gamma^{-1}(\mu,V,a,b)Œ≤,œÉ2‚àºNŒì‚àí1(Œº,V,a,b)Ôªø‚Äã
which is equivalent to:
œÉ2‚àºInvGamma(a,b)Œ≤‚à£œÉ2‚àºN(Œº,œÉ2V)\sigma^2\sim InvGamma(a,b)\\\beta|\sigma^2\sim N(\mu,\sigma^2 V)œÉ2‚àºInvGamma(a,b)Œ≤‚à£œÉ2‚àºN(Œº,œÉ2V)Ôªø‚Äã
so:
p(Œ≤,œÉ2)‚àù(œÉ2)‚àíp/2(œÉ2)‚àía‚àí1e‚àí1œÉ2(b+(Œ≤‚àíŒº)TV‚àí1(Œ≤‚àíŒº))p(\beta,\sigma^2)\propto (\sigma^2)^{-p/2}(\sigma^2)^{-a-1}e^{-\frac{1}{\sigma^2}(b+(\beta-\mu)^TV^{-1}(\beta-\mu))}p(Œ≤,œÉ2)‚àù(œÉ2)‚àíp/2(œÉ2)‚àía‚àí1e‚àíœÉ21‚Äã(b+(Œ≤‚àíŒº)TV‚àí1(Œ≤‚àíŒº))Ôªø‚Äã
And if
Z‚àºN(WŒ≤,œÉ2I)Z\sim N(W\beta,\sigma^2I)Z‚àºN(WŒ≤,œÉ2I)Ôªø‚Äã
then the posterior is:
Œ≤,œÉ2‚à£z,W‚àºNŒì‚àí1(Œº‚àó,V‚àó,a‚àó,b‚àó)\beta,\sigma^2|z, W\sim N\Gamma^{-1}(\mu^*,V^*,a^*,b^*)Œ≤,œÉ2‚à£z,W‚àºNŒì‚àí1(Œº‚àó,V‚àó,a‚àó,b‚àó)Ôªø‚Äã
where
Œº‚àó=(V‚àí1+WTW)‚àí1(V‚àí1Œº+WTz)V‚àó=(V‚àí1+WTW)‚àí1a‚àó=a+N/2b‚àó=b+1/2[ŒºTV‚àí1Œº+zTz‚àí(Œº‚àó)T(V‚àó)‚àí1Œº‚àó]\mu^*=(V^{-1}+W^TW)^{-1}(V^{-1}\mu+W^Tz)\\V^*=(V^{-1}+W^TW)^{-1}\\a^*=a+N/2\\b^*=b+1/2\Big[\mu^TV^{-1}\mu+z^Tz-(\mu^*)^T(V^*)^{-1}\mu^*\Big]Œº‚àó=(V‚àí1+WTW)‚àí1(V‚àí1Œº+WTz)V‚àó=(V‚àí1+WTW)‚àí1a‚àó=a+N/2b‚àó=b+1/2[ŒºTV‚àí1Œº+zTz‚àí(Œº‚àó)T(V‚àó)‚àí1Œº‚àó]Ôªø‚Äã
If we use the Zellner‚Äôs g prior:
p(Œ≤‚à£œÉ2,g)‚àºN(0,œÉ2g(WTW)‚àí1)p(œÉ2)‚àº1œÉ2p(\beta|\sigma^2,g)\sim N(0,\sigma^2g(W^TW)^{-1})\\p(\sigma^2)\sim \frac{1}{\sigma^2}p(Œ≤‚à£œÉ2,g)‚àºN(0,œÉ2g(WTW)‚àí1)p(œÉ2)‚àºœÉ21‚ÄãÔªø‚Äã
and we find that the posterior is still Normal InvGamma, but his mean has become
Œº‚àó=gg+1(WTW)‚àí1WTz=gg+1Œ≤^\mu^*=\frac{g}{g+1}(W^TW)^{-1}W^Tz=\frac{g}{g+1}\hat{\beta}Œº‚àó=g+1g‚Äã(WTW)‚àí1WTz=g+1g‚ÄãŒ≤^‚ÄãÔªø‚Äã

3.4 Bayesian variable selection

We saw that for Ridge or l1l_1l1‚ÄãÔªø penalisation the problem was
maxŒ≤‚à£‚à£WŒ≤‚àíz‚à£‚à£2+Œª‚à£‚à£Œ≤‚à£‚à£1max_{\beta}||W\beta-z||^2+\lambda||\beta||_1maxŒ≤‚Äã‚à£‚à£WŒ≤‚àíz‚à£‚à£2+Œª‚à£‚à£Œ≤‚à£‚à£1‚ÄãÔªø‚Äã
In high-dimension, Lasso or l0l_0l0‚ÄãÔªø penalisation allows us to select features automatically. The ideal problem in this case is:
maxŒ≤‚à£‚à£WŒ≤‚àíz‚à£‚à£2‚àíŒª‚à£‚à£Œ≤‚à£‚à£0max_{\beta}||W\beta-z||^2-\lambda||\beta||_0maxŒ≤‚Äã‚à£‚à£WŒ≤‚àíz‚à£‚à£2‚àíŒª‚à£‚à£Œ≤‚à£‚à£0‚ÄãÔªø‚Äã
We still need to select Œª with AIC (Œª‚ÄÑ=‚ÄÑ1) or BIC (Œª‚ÄÑ=‚ÄÑ2log(n)).
If we think of variable selection as hypothesis testing, we can compute the Bayes factor for each variable.
We can think of variable selection as:
Œ≥j={1‚ÄÖ‚Ääif‚ÄÖ‚ÄäŒ≤j‚â†0:H1j0‚ÄÖ‚Ääif‚ÄÖ‚ÄäŒ≤j=0:H0j\gamma_j=\bigg\{\begin{array}{cc} 1\;if\;\beta_j\neq0:H_{1j}\\0\;if\;\beta_j=0:H_{0j}\end{array}Œ≥j‚Äã={1ifŒ≤j‚ÄãÓÄ†=0:H1j‚Äã0ifŒ≤j‚Äã=0:H0j‚Äã‚ÄãÔªø‚Äã
Bayesian testing in case of one hypothesis is
p[H0‚à£z]=11+1‚àíqqp(z‚à£H1)p(z‚à£H0)p[H_0|z]=\frac{1}{1+\frac{1-q}{q}\frac{p(z|H_1)}{p(z|H_0)}}p[H0‚Äã‚à£z]=1+q1‚àíq‚Äãp(z‚à£H0‚Äã)p(z‚à£H1‚Äã)‚Äã1‚ÄãÔªø‚Äã
We can then compute p(z|H1) and p(z|H0) to find the Bayes factor.
